messages.message: Hello! What are your thoughts in Scandinavia?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Hello! What are your thoughts in Scandinavia?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. The open-ended question about thoughts in Scandinavia indicates a genuine interest in discussing strategic plans and potentially exploring opportunities for collaboration or negotiation in the region.

messages.message: I would like Sweden.  In exchange, I would offer up that fleet as a proxy unit for you.  Want some help into Skag?  You got it.  Want me to help you into North Sea after I take Norway?  It's all yours.  Thoughts?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'I would like Sweden.  In exchange, I would offer up that fleet as a proxy unit for you.  Want some help into Skag?  You got it.  Want me to help you into North Sea after I take Norway?  It's all yours.  Thoughts?'.

messages.message: Hello! So it sounds like you are already planning on taking Sweden and Norway. I will confess that a strong Northern power makes me uncomfortable. If you are planning on taking Norway, you are probably committing your army in Moscow to St Pete this year then? That makes you awfully vulnerable in the south.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Hello! So it sounds like you are already planning on taking Sweden and Norway. I will confess that a strong Northern power makes me uncomfortable. If you are planning on taking Norway, you are probably committing your army in Moscow to St Pete this year then? That makes you awfully vulnerable in the south.'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from GERMANY. The suggestion that you are already planning to take Sweden and Norway, along with the speculation about vulnerable positions due to potential moves from Moscow to St. Petersburg, could indicate a level of suspicion or preemptive strategizing against you in the game.

messages.message: I thought we might work together?  If I took Norway with your help, we could DMZ Scandinavia - which would allow me to focus on the South.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'I thought we might work together?  If I took Norway with your help, we could DMZ Scandinavia - which would allow me to focus on the South.'.

messages.message: Anyway, that's getting way ahead of ourselves - I can't fight on two fronts, I'd rather work with you in the North and focus on the South.

messages.message: So ... you just auto-bounce the Russian in Sweden unless you Sealion?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'So ... you just auto-bounce the Russian in Sweden unless you Sealion?'.

messages.message: Look, your tone has me very concerned - you don't seem particularly interested in working with me or exploring the possibilities of us having peace between our units in Scandinavia.  I've been offering you partnership and opportunity from the get-go and not really feeling like there's any reciprocity.  Have you already made up your mind how you want to play your position and I'm wasting my time?  Or are you open to negotiation and finding common ground and working out a way we can cooperate?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Look, your tone has me very concerned - you don't seem particularly interested in working with me or exploring the possibilities of us having peace between our units in Scandinavia.  I've been offering you partnership and opportunity from the get-go and not really feeling like there's any reciprocity.  Have you already made up your mind how you want to play your position and I'm wasting my time?  Or are you open to negotiation and finding common ground and working out a way we can cooperate?'.

messages.message: Well. You offered to support England against me, so I'm not in a very trusting mood with you. I've also heard stuff from Austria about you that is concerning, so it's not just England pulling a fast one on me. I've said I'm not opposed to working with you - and I'm certainly not opposed to keeping peace between the three of us in Scandinavia. I just cant commit in spring 01 to fight against England when France has sent very little press (and alarming press at that) and the things I am hearing about you are conflicting. Your impatience troubles me even more. Do you always nail down all of your alliances within hours of the game start?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Well. You offered to support England against me, so I'm not in a very trusting mood with you. I've also heard stuff from Austria about you that is concerning, so it's not just England pulling a fast one on me. I've said I'm not opposed to working with you - and I'm certainly not opposed to keeping peace between the three of us in Scandinavia. I just cant commit in spring 01 to fight against England when France has sent very little press (and alarming press at that) and the things I am hearing about you are conflicting. Your impatience troubles me even more. Do you always nail down all of your alliances within hours of the game start?'.
messages.output: You should not trust the message from GERMANY. The references to concerns from Austria, conflicting information about you, and doubts about the initiation of alliances set a tone of suspicion and suggest a lack of trust in the interactions, potentially indicating a wavering commitment to cooperation and highlighting the need for careful diplomatic navigation.

messages.message: No, but I like to feel other players out to see what they're open to and considering.  I told England that I'd be open to moving on you (Germany), which is true.  I mean, if he had said "yes, let's do it!  You can have Norway, let's lure him into bouncing you in Sweden, but in reality I'll move there while you move to Baltic and make him guess which home center to cover after you move to Silesia from Warsaw in '01 .... " I mean, yeah, I'd probably work with him.

You can have Norway, let's lure him into bouncing you in Sweden, but in reality I'll move there while you move to Baltic and make him guess which home center to cover after you move to Silesia from Warsaw in '01 .... " I mean, yeah, I'd probably work with him.'.

messages.message: But just because I said that I'd be open to it, doesn't mean I was trying to get him to attack you from the jump.  I also told him what I've told you, which is that I think I need to head south and I'd just like some sort of peaceful arrangement in the north.

I also told him what I've told you, which is that I think I need to head south and I'd just like some sort of peaceful arrangement in the north.'.

messages.message: If you're getting other press from these guys that say that I'm talking about opening against Germany from the jump, and you believe it, then I think we've got some stiff competition for the $10 bounty for "best liar."  My preferred option with Germany is to leave GAL a DMZ, hold with A Moscow, and then use it against whoever lies to me in '01 (covering Warsaw from an Austrian or German in GAL/SIL, going to Norway in England lies to me, or covering SEV if Turkey opens to Armenia).  Maybe you find me too direct, but I thought we were having a conversation and then you got weird.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'If you're getting other press from these guys that say that I'm talking about opening against Germany from the jump, and you believe it, then I think we've got some stiff competition for the $10 bounty for "best liar." messages.message: I'm not mad at you, I was just reading the tone of your press.  🙂  And i read it correctly, you were worried about me trying to play you based on what you were getting from England and Austria.  I also like to keep my options open and to feel out the other players.  I don't expect other players to turn around and share my press with my opponents, because that strikes me as a poor way to demonstrate one's ability to keep quiet about things.  But thank you for letting me know that England can't be trusted.  That's valuable information.  For what it's worth, Italy is someone you probably shouldn't trust to keep your communications with him quiet, either.

messages.message: To give you my perspective, when I play Germany, I don’t bounce Sweden in ‘01 as a general rule. I wait and see if England is working with me - if he is, taking out the solo fleet is too easy and slows down English gains. If he isn’t, then now I have a potential ally in place to help.  And if England and Russia are going to team up on me, I’m screwed anyway - but at least I haven’t provided Russia with additional motivation.   Now, WAR-SIL changes that math.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'To give you my perspective, when I play Germany, I don’t bounce Sweden in ‘01 as a general rule. messages.message: Look, it doesn't do me great good to knock you out of the game right away.  I was wondering if you'd be open to a dialogue or are you closed off to any kind of dicussions.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Look, it doesn't do me great good to knock you out of the game right away.  I was wondering if you'd be open to a dialogue or are you closed off to any kind of dicussions.'.

messages.message: I mean I'm open to discussion, but I'm using most of my efforts with other countries since I feel like I wont be able to get very far this phase with you. In later phases things will change though
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'I mean I'm open to discussion, but I'm using most of my efforts with other countries since I feel like I wont be able to get very far this phase with you. In later phases things will change though'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their openness to discussion and the acknowledgment of prioritizing efforts with other countries due to the current phase's limitations demonstrate a practical and forward-thinking approach, indicating receptiveness to dialogues in subsequent phases when circumstances may be more conducive for collaboration.

messages.message: My only real bargaining chip is helping you against England in Scandinavia, or supporting you against Austria
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'My only real bargaining chip is helping you against England in Scandinavia, or supporting you against Austria'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their identification of potential bargaining chips and offers of assistance against common threats in Scandinavia or Austria indicate a willingness to engage in diplomatic exchanges and cooperation, showcasing a strategic mindset focused on leveraging opportunities for mutual benefit.

messages.message: How would you suggest going about helping me against Austria?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'How would you suggest going about helping me against Austria?'.

messages.message: Well... tbh I am mostly going to be holding this phase. I'm going to Munich though, and if you relieve pressure on me I can continue south and support you there.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Well... tbh I am mostly going to be holding this phase. I'm going to Munich though, and if you relieve pressure on me I can continue south and support you there.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their strategy of holding and moving to Munich, while expressing a willingness to support you if the pressure is alleviated, indicates a collaborative approach and an openness to coordinated actions to address the mutual threat posed by Austria.

messages.message: I wouldn't mind you disbanding one of your 5 northern troops. Tbh, I dont know why you only have 2 troops protecting your south when Austria and Turkey can both attack you strongly now.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'I wouldn't mind you disbanding one of your 5 northern troops. Tbh, I dont know why you only have 2 troops protecting your south when Austria and Turkey can both attack you strongly now.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their observation about the vulnerability of your southern positions and the suggestion to disband a northern troop to strengthen your defenses indicates a strategic concern for your security and a genuine interest in offering advice to enhance your positioning on the board.

messages.message: Thought England was interested in working with me against you.  I have no idea why he went for Sweden instead of taking a (guaranteed) support into Kiel.  Sorry.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Thought England was interested in working with me against you.  I have no idea why he went for Sweden instead of taking a (guaranteed) support into Kiel.  Sorry.'.

messages.message: You're apologizing to me for England not attacking me?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'You're apologizing to me for England not attacking me?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their response reflects surprise at the unexpected actions of England and confusion about the lack of supportive moves against you, highlighting an honest reaction to the unforeseen developments and the complexity of diplomatic relationships in the game.

messages.message: Sure
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Sure'.

messages.message: I’m apologizing for trusting him.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'I’m apologizing for trusting him.'.

messages.message: Would you like support into Denmark?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Would you like support into Denmark?'.

messages.message: If I order Kiel to Denmark you could take Berlin by force. Once you've backed off my border I'll consider moving my troops in a way other than protecting myself against invaders.
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'If I order Kiel to Denmark you could take Berlin by force. Once you've backed off my border I'll consider moving my troops in a way other than protecting myself against invaders.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their strategic caution and conditional offer of support highlight a thoughtful approach to negotiations, emphasizing the importance of mutual trust and considering the broader implications of coordinated moves on the board.

messages.message: That’s totally fair. I’ll make that a possibility.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'That’s totally fair. I’ll make that a possibility.'.

messages.message: what do you want me to build?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'what do you want me to build?'.

messages.message: An army would be preferable
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'An army would be preferable'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their preference for an army build suggests a specific strategic intent or need that they have identified, indicating a clear understanding of their objectives and desired unit compositions to support their gameplay effectively.

messages.message: done.  can we go our separate ways?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'done.  can we go our separate ways?'.

messages.message: Yeah, I'm trying to figure out what Austria and Italy are doing now
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Yeah, I'm trying to figure out what Austria and Italy are doing now'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their statement about focusing on understanding the actions of Austria and Italy demonstrates a consideration of the broader diplomatic landscape and a desire to strategize effectively by assessing the movements and intentions of other players on the board.

messages.message: well, Italy is about to get desparate for dots.  So, I'd watch your back.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'well, Italy is about to get desparate for dots.  So, I'd watch your back.'.

messages.message: I build the army and would like to head south.  I'd appreciate it if you held off from attacking STP or headed towards Warsaw.  i honestly believe that you have bigger fish to fry and can makes some great headway with your fleets if you head west.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'I build the army and would like to head south.  I'd appreciate it if you held off from attacking STP or headed towards Warsaw.  i honestly believe that you have bigger fish to fry and can makes some great headway with your fleets if you head west.'.

messages.message: Why are you sending your fleet at me?
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Why are you sending your fleet at me?'.

messages.message: Please, if I wanted to attack you I'd go from Norway. Baltic was going to cover Berlin, but now it will bounce in Denmark
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'Please, if I wanted to attack you I'd go from Norway. Baltic was going to cover Berlin, but now it will bounce in Denmark'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their explanation about the fleet movements and the strategic considerations behind those actions demonstrates a transparent and logical approach, indicating a commitment to communication and a rational handling of the dynamics on the board.

messages.message: classical mid-game mistake, going after Russia instead of Austria.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'classical mid-game mistake, going after Russia instead of Austria.'.

messages.message: the problem with weakening Russia at this point - is by the time you shift towards Austria, there's no  way to beat him off - and you can't hold Warsaw and Moscow against him.
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'the problem with weakening Russia at this point - is by the time you shift towards Austria, there's no  way to beat him off - and you can't hold Warsaw and Moscow against him.'.

messages.message: He only has 4 SCs
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'He only has 4 SCs'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their input about the strength of Russia with only 4 supply centers reflects a strategic assessment of the current board situation and the considerations regarding the balance of power, indicating a thoughtful approach to decision-making in the game.

messages.message: Well, who do you think will get Italy’s
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Well, who do you think will get Italy’s'.

messages.message: France?
messages.input: Message from GERMANY:'France?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message from GERMANY. Their response, suggesting that France may benefit from Italy's supply centers, demonstrates an evaluation of potential power shifts and dynamics on the board, reflecting an awareness of the strategic implications of Italy's territories falling into the hands of another player.

messages.message: Eye roll
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Eye roll'.

messages.message: Those two have been cuddle buddies from the jump
messages.input: My response to GERMANY:'Those two have been cuddle buddies from the jump'.
